summary: Email correspondence between defense and prosecution attorneys regarding a proposed protective order in the Ghislaine Maxwell case. The defense proposes modifications to discovery procedures, including allowing Maxwell to review discovery on a laptop while in custody, and addresses concerns about pretrial publicity and witness protections.

persons.name: Christian Everdell
persons.context: Sends the email forwarding Laura Menninger's message regarding the proposed protective order to the recipients.

persons.name: Mark S. Cohen
persons.context: Listed as a recipient (Cc) of the email regarding the protective order proposal.

persons.name: Jeff Pagliuca
persons.context: Listed as a recipient (Cc) of the email regarding the protective order proposal.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Primary author of the proposed protective order on behalf of the defense counsel, representing Ghislaine Maxwell. She details specific changes to the order and argues for her client's access to discovery materials.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: Referred to as 'our client' and 'her' in the email. The proposed protective order modifications are aimed at allowing her to review discovery materials while in pretrial detention at the MDC.

connections.description: Menninger is acting as defense counsel for Maxwell, proposing legal procedures for her client's access to discovery materials.
Everdell forwards Menninger's message to other counsel, indicating professional coordination on the legal case.
Both are attorneys involved in the case, with Cohen being a recipient of the correspondence regarding the protective order.
Both are attorneys involved in the case, with Pagliuca being a recipient of the correspondence regarding the protective order.

events.title: Drafting of Protective Order
events.description: The defense counsel drafts a proposed protective order for discovery in the Ghislaine Maxwell case, with specific modifications.

events.title: Email Transmission of Proposed Order
events.description: Christian Everdell forwards Laura Menninger's proposed protective order to other counsel, seeking agreement to file it as unopposed.

keyFacts: Defense counsel proposes allowing Ghislaine Maxwell, a pretrial detainee, to review all discovery materials on a government-provided laptop while in custody at the MDC.
The defense argues that both defense and government witnesses should be protected from harassment and intimidation, and should have equal footing regarding discovery access.
The proposed protective order removes a 'Highly Confidential' category and refines the definition of 'Confidential' information based on Second Circuit case law.
The email indicates concerns about pretrial publicity violations by prospective witnesses and their counsel, and a desire to avoid trying the case in the press.
